TopicTitle: Star One C4 and MSG-4 launch atop Ariane 5 ECA July 15th (pics heavy)

Articles.Content:
**This is flight VA224, Ariane 5's sixth launch this year.** 

**Watch it** [**Here**](http://www.arianespace.tv/) **!** 

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/24VA2hg-xYc?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

**Launch window** is 37 minutes long : 

-18h42-19h19 Kourou time, July 15th

-21h42-23h19 GMT, July 15th

-23h42-00h19 Paris time, July 15th-16th

Star One C4 is riding the rocket on top, and MSG-4 is under the SYLDAb bell. Star One C4 will be released first, 28 minutes after liftoff. MSG-4 will be released later, at around 40 minutes into the flight.

![386693Capturedcran102.png](http://img11.hostingpics.net/pics/386693Capturedcran102.png)

-**MSG-4** is a 2ton meteo satellite wich is part of the ESA's EUMETSAT satellite constellation. it is in the white room in this picture. It is normally surrounded by static solar cells (they are covered here.)

![1293-lg.jpg](http://www.arianespace.com/images/missionup-dates/2015/1293-lg.jpg)

-**Star One C4** is a 5.6ton telephone, television and radio satellite part of the Embratel Star One satellite constellation. Will cover Brasil and relay data in most Latin america and USA. It will be launched on a 70Ã‚Â° inclination GEO. (no actual pics found... ?)

> 
> I was confused about that too. Is that THE second stage? Or is that just some assembly housing that comes off when the stage is mated to the rocket? Or is that a large interstage skirt that drops off?

This is pretty much the whole second stage with an interstage fairing skirt (but i'm not 100% sure on this you may want to check it up). the interstage is big because the second stage engine, the HM-7B, is very long.

IIRC the interstage stays attached to the first stage during staging and falls off with it. 

Yes the ESC (second stage) is very small compared to the EPC (first stage) because Ariane 5 is basically a oversized first stage with a small second stage.

Just so that you get the idea : MECO and staging happen when the booster is already flying at around 6900-7000 m.s^-1 and is at about 170km above the surface !!

why more struts ? there are 6 of them here for such a small engine !

The 'outside' of the upper stage is the part which is more white than the rest. 

The section above it is fitted around the 'rounded' part of the stage's LH2 tank) - it contains the various avionics / guidance units of the rocket, and serve as a support for the payload adapter.

The section below it is the interstage, which will fall with the core stage on separation. 

Also not shown on those pictures, but the upper stage will be fitted with ullage packs (which are also dropped once they did their job - those allow the fuel to settle in the tanks prior to the upper stage ignition, and push the upper stage away from the lower stage after separation)

The upper stage contains the RCS systems for the rocket (Roll control after booster separation (the SRBs are gimballed and can provide roll control during early ascent, but after booster separation, the single engine can only provide yaw & pitch control, so roll is done with RCS) once the core stage is dropped, full attitude control can be done with RCS (yaw, pitch & roll)
